frontmatter.title: Runtime API Reference
frontmatter.description: Complete API documentation for Skeleton Crew Runtime

children.value:
title: Runtime API Reference
description: Complete API documentation for Skeleton Crew Runtime
path: /api/runtime
order: 1
Complete reference documentation for the Skeleton Crew Runtime and all its subsystems.
The main orchestrator that initializes and coordinates all subsystems.
Registers a plugin with the runtime.
Error if plugin with same name is already registered.
Initializes the runtime and all registered plugins.
Error if already initialized or if plugin setup fails.
Disposes the runtime and cleans up resources.

runtime.screens: ScreenRegistry;  // Access screen registry
runtime.actions: ActionEngine;    // Access action engine
runtime.events: EventBus;         // Access event bus
runtime.plugins: PluginRegistry;  // Access plugin registry
Unified API provided to plugins during setup.
Error if screen with same ID already exists.
Error if action with same ID already exists.
Error if action doesn't exist or handler throws.

const actions = context.actions.getAllActions();
console.log('Available actions:', actions);
Pub/sub event system for cross-plugin communication.
Emits an event to all listeners.
Removes all listeners for an event type, or all listeners if no type specified.
Checks if a plugin is registered.
Event handlers should handle their own errors:
If a plugin's setup fails, the runtime initialization will fail:
Errors thrown in action handlers will be propagated to the caller. Errors in event handlers should be caught and handled within the handler to prevent affecting other listeners.
for more examples and best practices.

codeBlocks.code: const runtime = new Runtime(options?: RuntimeOptions);
await runtime.initialize();
await runtime.dispose();

runtime.screens: ScreenRegistry;  // Access screen registry
runtime.actions: ActionEngine;    // Access action engine
runtime.events: EventBus;         // Access event bus
runtime.plugins: PluginRegistry;  // Access plugin registry

const screens = context.screens.getAllScreens();
console.log(`Total screens: ${screens.length}`);

const actions = context.actions.getAllActions();
console.log('Available actions:', actions);
type EventHandler = (data: any) => void;

frontmatter.title: Build System
frontmatter.description: Understanding the Documentation Engine build system and hot reload

children.value:
title: Build System
description: Understanding the Documentation Engine build system and hot reload
path: /build-system
order: 6
- You are viewing the latest documentation.
Documentation Engine uses a build-time optimization strategy where markdown files are pre-parsed for fast loading. This page explains how the build system works and how to use it effectively.
The build system has two main components:
- Converts markdown to JSON at build time
Large bundle size (~500KB+ for markdown parser)
Slow initial page load (parsing on every visit)
Small bundle size (~50KB for core runtime)
You don't need to run it when:

# Parse markdown files manually
npm run build:parser

# Start development server (includes hot reload)
npm run dev

# Build for production (includes build:parser automatically)
npm run build

# Preview production build
npm run preview
, a custom Vite plugin watches the
folder and automatically rebuilds when you edit markdown files:
When you save a markdown file during development:

[docs-watcher] Detected change in docs/getting-started.md
[docs-watcher] Rebuilding parsed-content.json...

Starting build-time markdown parsing...
Docs directory: /path/to/docs
Found 11 markdown files
Parsing getting-started.md...
Successfully parsed 11 files

[docs-watcher] Rebuild complete! Reloading page...
With the hot reload plugin, you can edit markdown files and see changes immediately without running any commands manually!

# 1. Start dev server (one time)
npm run dev

# 2. Edit markdown files
vim docs/getting-started.md

# 3. Save the file
# (Hot reload plugin automatically rebuilds and reloads browser)

# 4. See changes immediately in browser!

# 1. Clone the repository
git clone <repo-url>

# 2. Install dependencies
npm install

# 3. Parse markdown files (first time only)
npm run build:parser

# 4. Start dev server
npm run dev

# Single command builds everything
npm run build

# Netlify
netlify deploy --dir=dist

# Vercel
vercel --prod

# GitHub Pages
gh-pages -d dist
Edited markdown but changes don't show
Hot reload plugin not detecting changes
Look for parsing errors in console
Total time to see changes: ~2 seconds

# Just run once and edit freely
npm run dev

# Ensures latest content is included
npm run build

# Include in version control
git add public/parsed-content.json
git commit -m "Update parsed content"

# .github/workflows/deploy.yml
- name: Build
  run: npm run build

codeBlocks.code:

frontmatter.title: Callout Example
frontmatter.description: This page demonstrates the Callout component with different types.

children.value:
title: Callout Example
description: This page demonstrates the Callout component with different types.
path: /callout-example
order: 4
This is an informational callout. Use it to provide helpful tips or additional context.
This is a warning callout. Use it to alert users about potential issues or important considerations.
This is an error callout. Use it to highlight critical issues or errors that need immediate attention.
You can also use callouts without a title. The icon will still be displayed based on the type.
To use the Callout component in your markdown files, simply use the following syntax:

<Callout type="info" title="Optional Title">
Your content here
</Callout>

codeBlocks.code:
<Callout type="info" title="Optional Title">
Your content here
</Callout>

frontmatter.title: Getting Started
frontmatter.description: Welcome to the Documentation Engine! This guide will help you get up and running quickly.

children.value:
title: Getting Started
description: Welcome to the Documentation Engine! This guide will help you get up and running quickly.
path: /getting-started
order: 2
- You are viewing the latest documentation.

Documentation Engine is a powerful, plugin-driven documentation system built on Skeleton Crew Runtime. It transforms markdown files into beautiful, interactive documentation websites with features like:
npm install skeleton-crew-runtime unified remark react react-dom minisearch prismjs

my-docs/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/              # Your markdown files
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.md
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ guides/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ plugins/       # Documentation plugins
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ components/    # React components
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html         # Entry point
Create a markdown file in the

---
title: My First Page
description: This is my first documentation page
path: /my-first-page
order: 1
---

# My First Page

Welcome to my documentation!

## Features

- Easy to write
- Beautiful output
- Interactive components
The frontmatter supports the following fields:
Code blocks are automatically syntax highlighted:
You can embed interactive components in your markdown:
Make sure to register components with the Component Registry before using them in markdown files.

<Callout type="info" title="Helpful Tip">
This is an informational callout!
</Callout>
Documentation Engine uses a build-time optimization where markdown files are pre-parsed for fast loading:

# Parse markdown files (required after adding/modifying docs)
npm run build:parser

# Start development server
npm run dev

# Build for production (includes build:parser automatically)
npm run build

# Preview production build
npm run preview
Add new markdown files to the
which the browser loads at runtime.
, a custom Vite plugin automatically watches the
Triggers a full page reload in your browser
- the Vite plugin handles it automatically.
Create a new markdown file in

echo "---
title: New Page
path: /new-page
---

# New Page

Content here" > docs/new-page.md
The page will automatically appear in the sidebar navigation and be searchable!
Now that you have the basics, explore these topics:
- Learn how to create custom plugins
Check out the full documentation or join our community for support!

frontmatter.title: Plugin Development
frontmatter.description: Learn how to create custom plugins for Documentation Engine

children.value:
title: Plugin Development
description: Learn how to create custom plugins for Documentation Engine
path: /guides/plugins
order: 1
Plugins are the heart of the Documentation Engine. This guide will teach you how to create powerful, reusable plugins.
Every plugin follows the same structure:
Plugins are initialized in a specific order:
: Plugin is registered with the runtime
: Plugin can register screens, actions, and event listeners
: Plugin responds to events and executes actions
Plugins are initialized in the order they are registered. Make sure to register dependencies first!
The RuntimeContext provides access to all runtime subsystems:
Screens represent pages or views in your application:
) to avoid conflicts with other plugins.
Here's a complete theme plugin implementation:
Always prefix your action and event IDs with your plugin name:
If your plugin creates resources, clean them up:
Don't let errors crash the entire application:
Provide clear documentation for your plugin's API:
If your plugin depends on another plugin:
If your plugin needs async setup:
Register screens dynamically based on data:
Now that you understand plugins, check out the
for detailed documentation of all available APIs.

frontmatter.title: Home
frontmatter.description: Welcome to the Documentation Engine - A powerful plugin-driven documentation system

children.value:
title: Home
description: Welcome to the Documentation Engine - A powerful plugin-driven documentation system
path: /
order: 1
- You are viewing the latest documentation.

Documentation Engine is a modern, plugin-driven documentation system built on Skeleton Crew Runtime. Transform your markdown files into beautiful, interactive documentation websites with powerful features out of the box.
Documentation Engine showcases the power of Skeleton Crew's plugin architecture, demonstrating how complex applications can be built using simple, composable plugins.
- Write content in markdown with embedded React components
- Fast, client-side search powered by MiniSearch
- Live code editors with real-time preview
- Works perfectly on mobile, tablet, and desktop
- Export to static HTML for fast hosting

# Install dependencies
npm install skeleton-crew-runtime unified remark react react-dom

# Create your first markdown file
echo "# Hello World" > docs/index.md

# Initialize the runtime
npm run dev
Here's a simple markdown file with frontmatter:

---
title: My Page
description: A simple documentation page
path: /my-page
order: 1
---

# My Page

Welcome to my documentation!

## Code Example

```javascript
console.log('Hello, Documentation Engine!');
```
Documentation Engine supports MDX components for rich, interactive content:
This is a live callout component! You can use these to highlight important information in your documentation.
Documentation Engine is built on a plugin architecture:

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ     Skeleton Crew Runtime           ‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§
‚îÇ  Plugins:                           ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Router       ‚Ä¢ Markdown Parser   ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Search       ‚Ä¢ Syntax Highlight  ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Theme        ‚Ä¢ Playground        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Versioning   ‚Ä¢ Cache             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  ‚Ä¢ Static Export                    ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
Each plugin is independent and composable, making it easy to customize or extend functionality.
- Understanding hot reload and build process
Documentation Engine supports syntax highlighting for many languages:
- Set up your first documentation site
Documentation Engine is built with open source technologies and demonstrates best practices for plugin-driven architecture.
Built with ‚ù§Ô∏è using Skeleton Crew Runtime

children.value:
title: Playground Example
description: Interactive code playground demonstration
path: /playground-example
order: 3
This page demonstrates the interactive code playground feature.
Try editing the code below and see the output update in real-time:
This playground includes preset examples you can switch between:

value.raw: console.log("Select an example from the dropdown!");
value.cooked: console.log("Select an example from the dropdown!");

children.value: The playground handles errors gracefully without crashing the page:

value.raw:
// This will throw an error
throw new Error("This is a test error!");
value.cooked:
// This will throw an error
throw new Error("This is a test error!");

children.value: : Code changes are debounced and executed automatically
: Errors are caught and displayed without crashing
: Your code is saved in session storage
: See console.log output in the preview pane

props.initialCode: console.log("Select an example from the dropdown!");

// This will throw an error
throw new Error("This is a test error!");

description: Welcome to Documentation Engine v1.0

order: 0
You are viewing documentation for version 1.0.
for the most recent features and improvements.
Documentation Engine v1.0 was the initial release demonstrating the power of Skeleton Crew Runtime for building plugin-driven documentation websites.
The latest version includes many improvements:
to see all the new features!

This versioning feature demonstrates how Documentation Engine can manage multiple documentation versions seamlessly, allowing users to access historical documentation while encouraging upgrades to the latest version.
